awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Measurement of Particle Aggregation in Laboratory-scale Flows for Improved Models of Volcanic Ash Fallout and Entrainment
awd_abstract_narration:
Volcanic eruptions produce clouds of ash, which are hazardous to air travel and infrastructure.  In emergencies, forecasters predict the transport of ash using numerical models, but they typically assume that particles fall as individuals to simplify the analysis.  In reality, fine ash particles combine together into larger clusters, accelerating their rate of fall.  This allows the ash to fall out of the cloud.  Rates of aggregation depend on many factors, including moisture, electric charge, and turbulence.  There is limited existing data on the effects of these properties, particularly for turbulent flows, even though aggregation affects up to 95% of fallout in some eruptions.  Hence, there is a need for better experimental measurements of aggregation processes, along with more advanced models that include the phenomenon.

This study aims to improve forecasting of volcanic hazards through both high-accuracy experiments and upgraded models.  Ash aggregation will be examined in two different, relevant flow conditions: homogeneous turbulence and high-speed jets.  High-resolution optical techniques will be used to study the flow, turbulence, and particle clustering.  The results will be integrated into state-of-the-art analytical models, including some used for forecasting.  Further, this research will be presented to the broader public through a series of hands-on demonstrations at the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry (OMSI).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Volcanic eruptions produce clouds of ash, which are hazardous to air travel and infrastructure. In emergencies, forecasters predict the transport of ash using numerical models, but they typically assume that particles fall as individuals to simplify the analysis. In reality, fine ash particles combine together into larger clusters, accelerating their rate of fall. This allows the ash to fall out of the cloud. Rates of aggregation depend on many factors, including moisture, electric charge, and turbulence. There is limited existing data on the effects of these properties, particularly for turbulent flows, even though aggregation affects up to 95% of fallout in some eruptions. Hence, there is a need for better experimental measurements of aggregation processes, along with more advanced models that include the phenomenon.
This study aims to improve forecasting of volcanic hazards through both high-accuracy experiments and upgraded models. Ash aggregation will be examined in two different, relevant flow conditions: homogeneous turbulence and high-speed jets. High-resolution optical techniques will be used to study the flow, turbulence, and particle clustering. The results are to be integrated into state-of-the-art analytical models, including some used for forecasting. Further, this research will be presented to the broader public through a series of hands-on demonstrations at the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry (OMSI).

An extensive experimental campaign was conducted to better understand the tendencies of particles within shearing flows. Specifically, a Lagrangian study of an axisymmetric turbulent water jet was performed and stereoscopic particle tracking velocimetry was invoked to create three component tracks of position, velocity and acceleration of the tracer (fluid elements). Furthermore, particles of varying size and weight were used to seed the flow in order to provide a range of inertial effects based on the particle interaction with the fluid (the Stokes number). The spatial and temporal resolution allow both Eulerian (fixed point) and Lagrangian (moving frame) fields to be analyzed. The application of these results is on the modeling of particle dynamics.

Using these data, characterization of relevant constants in the flow related to the Lagrangian dynamics have been quantified. Furthermore, a process for stationarizing the flow has been suggested which can prove useful when dealing with non-homogeneous flows. Improvements to models have been attained both for more canonical flows (homogeneous isotropic turbulence) with neutrally buoyant particles as well as including effects to account for particle inertia. Consideration of statistics second order moments of the flow/particles has been done in light of the variation in Stokes number. Similarity analysis of a turbulent jet has been revisited with the aim of arriving at the eddy viscosity and dispersion; this can aid in quantifying scalar fields of turbulent jets.

Efforts in discerning the effects of Stokes number and mass loading have been undertaken by analyzing particle-laden jets on air; experiments performed at WSU Vancouver. This dependence is necessary in the understanding of the flow behavior of the jets. Mean velocities, Reynolds stresses and Voronoi tessellations are all considered for the quantification of these differences.

Throughout the study, we performed educational outreach at the Oregon Museum of Science & Industry (OMSI), disseminating the findings to the general public through a permanent, hands-on demonstration.  We developed an interactive, hands-on activity on particle size distribution, which was being presented periodically. We have presented the work at the American Physical Society ? Division of Fluid Dynamics conference. Currently, three peer-reviewed articles have been published. Two articles are currently under review and two more are under preparation. It is expected that other publications will be a product of the data/experiments conducted. Two graduate students have been involved in the project. A PhD dissertation will also result from this work.


Last Modified: 10/11/2021
Modified by: Raul Cal
